pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:0.5.eng: 7. The training rule on more than that

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.1.eng: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū acchinnacīvarake bhikkhū upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadanti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.2.eng: the monks from the group of six said to the monks whose robes had been stolen,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.4.pli: ‘acchinnacīvarassa vā naṭṭhacīvarassa vā aññātakaṃ gahapatiṃ vā gahapatāniṃ vā cīvaraṃ viññāpetuṃ’;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.4.eng: a monk whose robes have been stolen or lost to ask an unrelated householder for a robe.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.5.eng: You should ask for a robe.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.6.eng: “It’s not necessary. We’ve already gotten robes.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.9.pli: Atha kho chabbaggiyā bhikkhū gahapatike upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.9.eng: The monks from the group of six then went to householders and said,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.10.eng: “Monks have arrived whose robes have been stolen.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.12.eng: And they asked for many robes.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.13.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro puriso sabhāyaṃ nisinno aññataraṃ purisaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.13.eng: Soon afterwards in the public meeting hall a certain man said to another,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.14.eng: “Sir, monks have arrived whose robes have been stolen.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.18.eng: They complained and criticized those monks,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.19.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā na mattaṃ jānitvā bahuṃ cīvaraṃ viññāpessanti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.19.eng: “How can the Sakyan monastics ask for many robes without moderation?

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.20.pli: dussavāṇijjaṃ vā samaṇā sakyaputtiyā karissanti, paggāhikasālaṃ vā pasāressantī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.20.eng: Are they going to trade in cloth or set up shop?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.21.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.21.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.22.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.22.eng: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.23.pli: “kathañhi nāma chabbaggiyā bhikkhū na mattaṃ jānitvā bahuṃ cīvaraṃ viññāpessantī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.23.eng: “How could the monks from the group of six ask for many robes without moderation?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.24.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū chabbaggiye bhikkhū anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.24.eng: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.25.pli: “saccaṃ kira tumhe, bhikkhave, na mattaṃ jānitvā bahuṃ cīvaraṃ viññāpethā”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.25.eng: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.28.pli: kathañhi nāma tumhe, moghapurisā, na mattaṃ jānitvā bahuṃ cīvaraṃ viññāpessatha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.28.eng: “Foolish men, how could you do this?

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.30.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.30.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.31.1.pli: “Tañce aññātako gahapati vā gahapatānī vā bahūhi cīvarehi abhihaṭṭhuṃ pavāreyya santaruttaraparamaṃ tena bhikkhunā tato cīvaraṃ sāditabbaṃ. Tato ce uttari sādiyeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:1.31.1.eng: ‘If an unrelated male or female householder invites that monk to take many robes, he should accept at most one sarong and one upper robe. If he accepts more than that, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.2.eng: the monk whose robes have been stolen.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.4.pli: mātito vā pitito vā yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā asambaddho.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.4.eng: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back eight generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.4.comm: Sp 1.505: Tattha yāva sattamā pitāmahayugāti pitupitā pitāmaho, pitāmahassa yugaṁ pitāmahayugaṁ, “In this yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means: the father of a father is a grandfather. The generation of a grandfather is called a pitāmahayuga.” So the PaIi phrase yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means “as far as the seventh generation of grandfathers”, that is, eight generations back. This can be counted as follows: (1) one’s grandfather; (2) his father; (3) 2’s father; (4) 3’s father; (5) 4’s father; (6) 5’s father; and (7) 6’s father. This applies to both one’s paternal and maternal grandfathers. This gives a total of 14 ancestors. Anyone who is a descendent of these fourteen is considered a relative. Anyone who is not such a descendent is not regarded as a relative.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.6.eng: any man who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.6.comm: Agāraṁ is typically rendered as “in a house”. The problem with this is that it is not unallowable for a monastic to live in a building that is the equivalent of a house. What a monastic should not do is own a home and then live there.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.8.eng: any woman who lives at home.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.12.eng: saying, “Take as many as you like.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.13.pli: Santaruttaraparamaṃ tena bhikkhunā tato cīvaraṃ sāditabbanti
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.13.eng: He should accept at most one sarong and one upper robe:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.14.pli: sace tīṇi naṭṭhāni honti dve sāditabbāni, dve naṭṭhāni ekaṃ sāditabbaṃ, ekaṃ naṭṭhaṃ na kiñci sāditabbaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.14.eng: if three robes are lost, he should accept two; if two robes are lost, he should accept one; if one robe is lost, he should not accept any.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.15.eng: If he accepts more than that:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.16.eng: if he asks for more than that, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.17.eng: When he gets the robe, it becomes subject to relinquishment.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.18.pli: Nissajjitabbaṃ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.18.eng: The robe should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.19.eng: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.20.eng: (To be expanded as in Bu NP 1:3.2.5–3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.21.pli: “idaṃ me, bhante, cīvaraṃ aññātakaṃ gahapatikaṃ upasaṅkamitvā tatuttari viññāpitaṃ nissaggiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.21.eng: ‘Venerables, this robe, which I received after asking an unrelated householder for too many, is to be relinquished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.22.eng: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.1.25.eng: ‘I give this robe back to you.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.1.1.pli: Aññātake aññātakasaññī tatuttari cīvaraṃ viññāpeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.1.1.eng: If the person is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such, and he asks them for too many robes, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.2.pli: Aññātake vematiko tatuttari cīvaraṃ viññāpeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.2.eng: If the person is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it, and he asks them for too many robes, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.3.pli: Aññātake ñātakasaññī tatuttari cīvaraṃ viññāpeti, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.3.eng: If the person is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related, and he asks them for too many robes, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.4.eng: If the person is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.5.eng: If the person is related, but the monk is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.2.6.eng: If the person is related and the monk perceives them as such, there is no offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.2.eng: if he takes too much, but with the intention of returning the remainder;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.2.comm: Sp 1.526: Sesakaṁ āharissāmīti dve cīvarāni katvā sesaṁ puna āharissāmīti attho, “Sesakaṁ āharissāmi: the meaning is that he says, ‘After making two robes, I will return the remainder.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.3.eng: if they give, saying, “The remainder is for you;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.3.comm: Presumably this refers to any leftover cloth after the robe(s) have been made.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.4.eng: if they give, but not because his robes were stolen;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.5.eng: if they give, but not because his robes were lost;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.7.eng: if it is from those who have given an invitation;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.8.eng: if it is by means of his own property;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.10.eng: if he is the first offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np7:2.3.11.eng: The training rule on more than that, the seventh, is finished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:0.5.eng: 8. The training rule on what is set aside

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.1.eng: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro puriso pajāpatiṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.2.eng: a certain man said to his wife,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.3.eng: “I’m going to give robe-cloth to Venerable Upananda.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.4.pli: Assosi kho aññataro piṇḍacāriko bhikkhu tassa purisassa imaṃ vācaṃ bhāsamānassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.4.eng: An alms-collecting monk heard that man making that statement.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.5.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu yenāyasmā upanando sakyaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.5.eng: He then went to Upananda the Sakyan and said,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.7.pli: Amukasmiṃ okāse aññataro puriso pajāpatiṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.7.eng: In such-and-such a place I heard a man tell his wife

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.8.eng: that he’s going to give you robe-cloth.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.10.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto yena so puriso tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ purisaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.10.eng: Upananda then went to that man and said,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.11.pli: “saccaṃ kira maṃ tvaṃ, āvuso, cīvarena acchādetukāmosī”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.11.eng: “Is it true that you want to give me robe-cloth?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.13.eng: that’s just what I was thinking.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.14.pli: “Sace kho maṃ tvaṃ, āvuso, cīvarena acchādetukāmosi, evarūpena cīvarena acchādehi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.14.eng: “If that’s the case, give me such-and-such robe-cloth.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.15.pli: Kyāhaṃ tena acchannopi karissāmi yāhaṃ na paribhuñjissāmī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.15.eng: For what’s the point of giving robe-cloth that I won’t use?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.16.pli: Atha kho so puriso ujjhāyati khiyyati vipāceti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.16.eng: That man complained and criticized him,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.17.eng: “These Sakyan monastics have great desires. They’re not content.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.18.eng: It’s no easy matter to give them robe-cloth.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.19.pli: Kathañhi nāma ayyo upanando mayā pubbe appavārito maṃ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjissatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.19.eng: How could Venerable Upananda come to me and say what kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited by me to do so?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.20.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tassa purisassa ujjhāyantassa khiyyantassa vipācentassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.20.eng: The monks heard the complaints of that man,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.21.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.21.eng: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized him,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.22.pli: “kathañhi nāma āyasmā upanando sakyaputto pubbe appavārito gahapatikaṃ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjissatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.22.eng: “How could Venerable Upananda go to a householder and say what kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited to do so?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.23.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.23.eng: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.24.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, upananda, pubbe appavārito gahapatikaṃ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjasī”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.24.eng: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.28.pli: “Aññātako, moghapurisa, aññātakassa na jānāti patirūpaṃ vā appatirūpaṃ vā santaṃ vā asantaṃ vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.28.eng: “Foolish man, people who are unrelated don’t know what’s appropriate and inappropriate, what’s good and bad, in dealing with each other.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.29.pli: Tattha nāma tvaṃ, moghapurisa, pubbe appavārito aññātakaṃ gahapatikaṃ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjissasi.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.31.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.31.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.32.1.pli: “Bhikkhuṃ paneva uddissa aññātakassa gahapatissa vā gahapatāniyā vā cīvaracetāpannaṃ upakkhaṭaṃ hoti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.32.1.eng: ‘If a male or female householder has set aside a robe fund for an unrelated monk, thinking,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.33.pli: ‘iminā cīvaracetāpannena cīvaraṃ cetāpetvā itthannāmaṃ bhikkhuṃ cīvarena acchādessāmī’ti;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.33.eng: “With this robe fund I will buy robe-cloth and give it to monk so-and-so;”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.34.pli: tatra ce so bhikkhu pubbe appavārito upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjeyya—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.34.eng: and if that monk, without first being invited, goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, saying,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.35.pli: ‘sādhu vata maṃ āyasmā iminā cīvaracetāpannena evarūpaṃ vā evarūpaṃ vā cīvaraṃ cetāpetvā acchādehī’ti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.35.eng: “Please use this robe fund to buy such-and-such robe-cloth and then give it to me,”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.36.eng: and he does so because he wants something fine, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.2.pli: bhikkhussatthāya, bhikkhuṃ ārammaṇaṃ karitvā, bhikkhuṃ acchādetukāmo.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.2.eng: for the benefit of a monk; making a monk the object of consideration, one wants to give to him.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.4.pli: mātito vā pitito vā yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā asambaddho.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.4.eng: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back eight generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.4.comm: Sp 1.505: Tattha yāva sattamā pitāmahayugāti pitupitā pitāmaho, pitāmahassa yugaṁ pitāmahayugaṁ, “In this yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means: the father of a father is a grandfather. The generation of a grandfather is called a pitāmahayuga.” So the PaIi phrase yāva sattamā pitāmahayuga means “as far as the seventh generation of grandfathers”, that is, eight generations back. This can be counted as follows: (1) one’s grandfather; (2) his father; (3) 2’s father; (4) 3’s father; (5) 4’s father; (6) 5’s father; and (7) 6’s father. This applies to both one’s paternal and maternal grandfathers. This gives a total of 14 ancestors. Anyone who is a descendent of these fourteen is considered a relative. Anyone who is not such a descendent is not regarded as a relative.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.6.eng: any man who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.6.comm: Agāraṁ is typically rendered as “in a house”. The problem with this is that it is not unallowable for a monastic to live in a building that is the equivalent of a house. What a monastic should not do is own a home and then live there.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.8.eng: any woman who lives at home.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.10.pli: hiraññaṃ vā suvaṇṇaṃ vā muttā vā maṇi vā pavāḷo vā phaliko vā paṭako vā suttaṃ vā kappāso vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.10.eng: money, gold, a pearl, a gem, a coral, a crystal, cloth, thread, or cotton wool.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.10.comm: “Money” renders hirañña. See Appendix of Technical Terms for discussion.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.12.eng: with that which is at one’s disposal.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.18.pli: yaṃ bhikkhuṃ uddissa cīvaracetāpannaṃ upakkhaṭaṃ hoti so bhikkhu.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.18.eng: the monk the robe fund has been set aside for.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.20.pli: pubbe avutto hoti— “kīdisena te, bhante, cīvarena attho, kīdisaṃ te cīvaraṃ cetāpemī”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.20.eng: he or she has not said beforehand: “Venerable, what kind of robe-cloth do you need? What kind of robe-cloth can I buy for you?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.22.eng: having gone to their house or having gone wherever.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.23.eng: Specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.24.pli: āyataṃ vā hotu vitthataṃ vā appitaṃ vā saṇhaṃ vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.24.eng: please make it long or wide or closely woven or soft.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.26.eng: that which is at one’s disposal.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.28.pli: Āyataṃ vā vitthataṃ vā appitaṃ vā saṇhaṃ vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.28.eng: long or wide or closely woven or soft.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.34.eng: wanting something good, wanting something expensive.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.35.pli: Tassa vacanena āyataṃ vā vitthataṃ vā appitaṃ vā saṇhaṃ vā cetāpeti, payoge dukkaṭaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.35.eng: If that lay person buys robe-cloth that is long, wide, closely woven, or soft because of the monk’s statement, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.36.eng: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.37.pli: Nissajjitabbaṃ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.37.eng: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.38.eng: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.39.eng: (To be expanded as in Bu NP 1:3.2.5–3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.40.pli: “idaṃ me, bhante, cīvaraṃ pubbe appavārito aññātakaṃ gahapatikaṃ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpannaṃ nissaggiyaṃ,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.40.eng: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I received after going to an unrelated householder and saying what kind of robe-cloth I wanted without first being invited, is to be relinquished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.41.eng: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.44.eng: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.1.pli: Aññātake aññātakasaññī pubbe appavārito gahapatikaṃ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjati, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.1.eng: If the householder is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.2.pli: Aññātake vematiko pubbe appavārito gahapatikaṃ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjati, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.2.eng: If the householder is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.3.pli: Aññātake ñātakasaññī pubbe appavārito gahapatikaṃ upasaṅkamitvā cīvare vikappaṃ āpajjati, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.3.eng: If the householder is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.4.eng: If the householder is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.5.eng: If the householder is related, but the monk is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.6.eng: If the householder is related and the monk perceives them as such, there is no offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.3.eng: if it is from those who have given an invitation;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.4.eng: if it is for the benefit of another;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.5.eng: if it is by means of his own property;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.6.eng: if the householder wishes to buy something expensive, but the monk has them buy something inexpensive;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.8.eng: if he is the first offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.9.eng: The training rule on what is set aside, the eighth, is finished.
